Very well stated! And I would say not off-topic at all, if you take the
vie=
w (as I think that we both do) that testing can also be done by
eliminating=
 things that need testing.

By eliminating sequence dependencies from your =
API, you have eliminated
a test condition and thereby made it easier to ver=
ify your object and
it's API. Anything that is made simpler has a by-produc=
t of being less
likely to break.

Also: JavaBeans can be used for good rath=
er than evil. I only use them
as data-holders, and use "real" objects for t=
he heavy lifting! :-)

Simon

>The "Samurai Principle" applies: return victorious, or=
 not at all.
>
>I have a rule: don't make me guess. It's a simple rule. One=
 
>consequence 
>of the rule is that when I create an object using your (an=
yone's) 
>constructor, I expect that object to be able to respond to anythi=
ng I 
>throw at it. If not, you shouldn't have let me create it.
>
>Notice =
that JavaBeans automatically fail on this rule. I have always 
>said that t=
hey are evil.
>
>As for using some kind of invariant assertion on the objec=
t, like an 
>"isValid", your unit tests should perhaps try to uncover any 
=
>place where 
>you might require your client to program "by accident" -- th=
at 
>is, know 
>the order in which to send messages to your object. If you =

>write a test 
>and think, "I can't call method X before I've called metho=
d Y," then 
>you're programming by accident. In the words of the great Bob =
Newhart, 
>"Stop it!" Either create a new method Z that calls X and Y in 
>=
that order 
>and remove X from the public eye or do something else to make =
it 
>impossible (as much as you can) for a client to write code 
>that blow=
s up.
>
>JBR.
